text:
What's up, guys? Happy Halloween! In this 
lesson we'll be-- Oh, wait. That's better!

In today's lesson we are going to be learning 
all about today's special event Halloween,

and we'll be learning about how it's 
celebrated in the US and the UK.

By the way every week we help you to learn fast 
English without getting lost, without missing the

jokes and without subtitles. In fact, this fan 
says that through our explanations he can now

understand scenes that he couldn't before. So if 
that sounds good to you don't forget to hit that

Subscribe button and the Bell down below, so that 
you don't miss a single one of our new lessons.

Do you find it difficult to understand fast 
speaking natives? Then I highly recommend

our Fluent with Friends Course. In this 48-week 
course you will learn with the first 2 seasons

of Friends. You'll receive PDF Power Lessons 
every week, vocabulary memorization software,

access to our Fluency Circle Global Cand so much 
more. And did you know you can try it right now

for FREE with our 3-Part Masterclass? All you have 
to do is click up here or down in the description

box below to learn more and sign up now. 
We look forward to seeing you there!

If you're enjoying this lesson then I highly 
recommend you check out our Friends playlist,

where you'll find a ton of 
fun lessons to watch next.

You can click up here or down in the 
description box below for that link.

Now another big difference between the UK and the 
US is the house decoration. Now, in the US people

put a lot of effort into decorating their houses, 
whereas in the UK this doesn't really happen that

frequently. The tradition of trick-or-treating 
only really became popular in the UK in the last

10 years or so. To be honest many families are 
quite afraid or a bit cautious of their children

knocking on strangers doors for candy or sweets.
In fact some people will not even open their doors

to trick-or-treaters, however if trick-or-treaters 
are welcome some people might decorate their

front door to show that they are welcome to 
knock on the door and say trick-or-treat.

In contrast this is a very popular tradition 
in the US and, in fact, if you don't open your

door to trick-or-treaters then they might even 
egg your house and throw toilet paper at it.
In Scotland it's very common for children to

do a performance or show a talent in return 
for some candy or some chocolate or sweets,

and what they tend to do as well in Scotland 
is they carve out turnips. So you may have

seen and heard that in the US they actually 
carve out pumpkins to make jack-o'-lanterns.

In the UK we celebrate guy fawkes 
night or bonfire night more,

and this happens on the 5th of November 
which is the date in which Guy Fawkes tried

to blow up the Houses of Parliament, 
and it's also known as the Gunpowder

Plot. So to commemorate this day we 
actually celebrate with fireworks.

And now I want to hear from you. How do 
you celebrate Halloween in your country?
Share it in the comments down below.

So I hope you enjoyed learning a little bit more 
about the culture in the UK and the US on this

special day, and if you're celebrating 
today I wish you all a Happy Halloween!
